div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,414] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, Every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindiel Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined sea and special train fare os 22.9.11 Port said to london via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London calling Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every altenate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:

From December 2nd until further notice the "Train de Luxe" composed exclusively of Sleeping and Restaurant Cars will every once Wednesday and Saturday at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor every Thursday and Sunday at the same hour. div.head: DISESTABLISHMENT IN FRANCE
div.p: Our telegrams during the last few days have contained accounts of various bitter conflicts in Paris and the provinces in regard to the disestablishment in France. No impartial ob server, we believe, will deny that the Catholic are under considerable provocation. They are expected to stand by while the State officials catalogue and appraise all those contents of their church which are not only sacro-sanct by reason of the uses to which they are applied, hat are the pledges of the personal faith and love of generations of pious souls. To see these symbols of their fai h taken, so to say, into the custody of an unfriendly Government under the pretence of "protecting" them—from what ?— but in reality for the purpose of being able to confiscate them en bloc, with the churches which contain them, on the slightest pretext afford ed must needs be galling in the extreme. The officials appear to be trying to obey orders without any unnecessary provocation, and with that courtesy which habitually lubricates life in France And, after all, they are only performing a formal act, submission to which by the faithful is not forbidden by any spiritual authority. Submission— under protest—is the coarse ordered, we believe, by the Bishops, and the episcopal direction would seem to be the only possible for good Christians and good citizens These alarams and excursions are, however, only the preliminary to a much more serious business. What is to be the attitude of the Church of France towards the Act of Separation as a whole ? With Rome, of course, the answer to that question rests, and since Rome has not yet spoken, the Catholics do not admit that causa finita est, and they are divided as to the course which principle and expediency alike should dictate. The great majority, we believe, including most of the Episcopate, would apply to the law as a whole the same principle of submission under protest which seems the plain duty in the particular case of the inventories. That principle is, clearly, based upon the duty of the Christian and the citizen. The law prescribes the formation of "Association Cultuelles" which shall take over the whole duty of the administration of the churches and ecclesiastical property. Wherever these are forme before the 1st of January next, the work of the Church will go on as if nothing had happened. Where these are not formal, the churches and their contents will pass into the hands of the local authorities and public worship will cease. In view of that alterca-tive the plain duty of the Catholics seems to be to emure the continuance of public) worship and the administration of the Sacraments, in accordance with a civil law which, whatever its demerits may be, has a claim to obedience. But some hold that when the nation sees the churches closed the majority will arise and wreak vengeance upon the Government responsible for their closure, and that, in the meantime, persecution will be an excellent tonic for French Catholicism. We doubt that very strongly. We believe that the French peasant —who has no lack of shrewdness — wou'd throw the blame of the closure upon its immediate and visible authors, the Catholics themselves, and that the hands of the enemies of all religion would be enormously strengthened. And as to persecution, well, persecution is a tonic which, to be efficacious, must be endured at the hands of the enemy, not self-imposed as a tactical expedient for political, quite as much as for spiritual, purposes. To repeat what we have said before,the Catholics will certainly be undertaking a grave responsibility if they deliberately deprive a single French man of the existing facilities for the practice of his religion, ard they will, in all probability, be playing straight into the hands of the enemy, who desires nothing better than to see every church in France closed. Principle and prudence, there-fore,alike seem to dic'ae the acceptance of the law, which, with all its defects, is not necessarily fatal, or even in principle inimical, the continued existence of the Church France. The Act of Separation, undoubtedly concedes a certain measure of liberty to rthe Church bat it deprives of her State-supplied income. The Church, therefore, will do well to use that liberty, and to use it with prudence, knowing, as she does that it is granted upon conditions. If we are not mistaken, the party of resistance is animated by a z''al which is by no means purely a z al for souls. the last word, of course, has yet to be spoken —from Rome. But, if Pius X. be a less skilful diplomatist than his great predecessor, there is no reason to believe that he is less anxious for the spiritual welfare of those Frenchmen who are still striving to prove that France —if a wayward child has not yet lost all right to her grand historic title of The Eldest Daughter of the Church.

Prince Lmi* Pnilippe d'Orleans and Bra- gance and his younger brother, Prince Antonio, who were thoronghly enjoying themselves at Mena Hoose Gymkhana on Monday afternoon, are staying at the Savoy Hotel. Prince Lonis is the eldest son of the late Comte de Paris and was born in Febraayy 1869. When he attained his majority he entered Paris, and, proceeding to the Marie, expressed his desire, as a Frenchman, to perform bis military service. It will be remembered by most of oar readers, however, that the Expalaion Bill of 1886 prohibited the direct heirs of the families which have reigned in France tr settle in that Country, and he was, therefore, arrested. His imprisonment was merely nominal and after a few months he was liberated by President Carnot and conducted to the Swiss Frontier, and on accnnnt of this e*oapade be was given the nickname of Le Premier Conacrtt. Daring the last illness of his father from Angast to September 1894 be was most assidnons in his attendance on the illastrioas patient, from whom, it is said, he received mnch advice concerning his datiesas thefatnre represented; ive of the family tradition After the funeral of the Comte de Paris, he received his adherents and before long retired to Brussels, where are now his hea l quarters. div.head: A HELOUAN SENSATION
div.p: HELOUAN, Wednesday.
Great excitement was caased in Helonan to-day by the spread of the news that a quarrel between two hotel oooks had ended in a most serions manner. s

It appears that the chef, a Swiss, and a Berberine cook had quarrelled on aooonnt of some matter in dispute between them. It is stated, that as a result of the quarrel,the Berberine took a knife and* madje * rush at the Swiss,whereupon the latter drew a revolver and fired two shots at his assailant The Swiss has been arrested. The affair caused a great sensation in the town.
According to infonqation in possession of the police the Berberine attacked rhe 8wiss fith a stick and the Swiss shot him in self-defence. The Berberine is in hospital.

div.head: LUXOR AMUSEMENTS
div.p: The Rev. Howard Agnew Johnson, D.D., is a Presbyterian divine and, we believe, an American. He has recently been on a visit to Ezypt and published some of bis impressions in an article, which ap eared in a religions magazine, entitled "The Herald and Presbyter." The article was sent to ns, and in view of the portion 1 f the Reverend author and the oh tract rof the magazine, we repoblished it. Bat it appears that the Rev. Howard Agnew John-on, who throughout the artiole is lond in hia pianes of the Presbyterian American Missionaries in Egypt, is not to be trashed when he comes to speak on Anglican divines, and the "odium theologioum" leads him to inaoouracy. Io the artiole in question, he Animadverted in strong terms on the manner in which the ' oanse of Christ" was hnrt by the example of the "Episcopal Chaplain" at Luxor. The ground for the displeasure of tbit American Presbyterian is that the Episcopalian Chaplain after "having read the servioe Sabbath mornirgs, he is the organizer of the afternoon excursions on that day," etc., etc. Organiz'Dg excursions on the Sabbath may oause indignation in the minds of some religions people. An instance is given by Mr. W. S. Gilbert, who in one of his ballads deals wifh the oase of three yooths who:—
Every Sabbath day they walked.
(Suoh was their gay thoughtless natur).
In parka or gardens, where they talked From three, to six, or even later.
This reprehensible conduct came within the cognizance of a clergyman of the name of Mackli- who
"Could in every action ahow
"Some ain, and nobody could doubt him." and cc n^eqnently
He wept to think each thoughtless youth Contained of wickednesa a akinfull And burnt to teach the awful truth That walking out on Sunday'a sinful.

Apparently the Rev. Howard A grew Johnson, D.D., is of the same opinion and consequently his conscience was stirred to its depthi when be heard that an Episcopalian cleric Organised exoarsiooa at Luxor on 8unday afternoon and in the week endeavoured to get up entertainments and other forms of amase- ment. This condaot moved him to ask "Is it strange that many Mahometans are very slow to believe that Christians are truly religions 1 '
Even if it had been true no sensible person would have objected to this condaot on the part of the Chaplain at Luxor.
But it appears that the assertions of this Presbyterian divine are qaite false for yesterday evening we received the following telegram from Luxor : —
To THE EDITOR OP THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—Referring to the extracts given in your paper from the * f^erald and Presbyter" and attributed to the Rev Howard A (new Johnson, DD., undet the title 'Redemptive Forces in Egypt," I wish to say, as a resident for the past three winter seasous at Luxor, that the remarks concerning the Episcopal clergyman amount to a t currilous libel on a respected and earnest Christian'gentleman and haye given mnoh pain to his nomerqaq friends here. Not on'y does he not organise Sanday excursions bat he has always steadfastly set his face against Sanday amasements in any form. He has never taken any part in the hotel dances. I mnoh hope that his brother olergy in this oonntry will indignantly protest against such an unwarrantable attack on one of their namber.—Yours, ek»
F. W. SAUNDERS, Luxor Hotel

div.head: BANQUET AT SHEPHEARD'S
div.p: A private and exclusive dinner tendered by Mr. Da> iel O'Day and his daughter Miss Rath O'Day of New York, in honor of the Rev. Father Grepgory, O.S.F., of 8t. Joseph's Cbnroh in Cairo, to which were invited several prominent Americans, to meet the Reverend Father, was served at Shepheard's on last Thnrsday evening. Mr. O'Day, the host, in addressing the dinner party, spoke eloqnently of Father Grepgory and the good work to which the Father and his brother Franciscans are devoting their energies end their lives. He expressed the hope that all visitor* to Egypt would recognize the need of fond* to aid the oanse of Christianity and subscribe substantially and speedily to the assistance of Father Greggory'g mission, saying "who gives qniokly gives doable." The host subsequently in a few happy remarks presented his old friend and follow voyager Dr. Bedloe of Washington, D.C , the Washington Correspondent of the Oil City Derrick, and requested him to respond to the toast of the occasion, "The Cbnroh."
Dr. Bedloe although hailing from America's Capital City is well k°own the world over, having represented the U.8. Government on three continents under Presidents Hayes',(Harrison, and MoKinlej.
In response to the call of Mr. O'Day and to the edification and delight of all present Dr. Bedloe said :
" I never drink snch a toast without recalling the vast debt ot gr*t>tade we owe to the ohnroh of the middle ages.
In the long gone years the ftyhari*«s and good fellows of Greece and Rom* quenched their tlrir*t. with rioh red wine.

To them John Barleycorn was a pe^f-ct stranger ; oognac and otard were sealed book*; and the thousand and one liquors of to-day were unborn. Champagne, the idealization of all vinons beverages, had not come into existence, while, as for panche* cocktails, fizzes, smashes, erg-nog, Tom and Jenry, shot Scotch and Irish, Ryeand Taos Moroney highballs of Boldt's Brilevne, S rat ford, Waldorf and Astoria the Greek and Latin tongoes, despite the genins of Homer and Plato, Virgil and Cioero **re overly unable to express or describe. Imagine it yon oan a dinner of to-day (by O'Day) in which the sole alleviates of thirst were wire and honey, w«ne and water, wine and more wa*er! When the inspired writer said 'look not opon the wine whm it is red,' perhaps he was looking forward 2,000 year's to our own time when there are other and better beverages. Yet such was the condition which ponfronted Laonllns, Apioins and other great bon vivants of antiquity.
! A small boy could give a better dinner today, so far as the wi e card is oo* earned, than could all the Cm-ars c*f the West and the Kings and Emperors of the East.

What made the change t Whit great power so wrought opon 1 ature as to give ns the wealth nf enjoyment we have to-day ? It was the Church, the noble abbots and hnmble monks who applied intellect to the world aronnd them and brought forth results which qgiil never die.
They took the culture of the vine firom pagan Rom? and they converted it into a new art and soienoe,
They dignifled their produots by giving to them religions terms and titles.

The golden juice of the grape in the Vesn- vian vintage became the ^Lachryrose Christ'," or tears of Christ; the amber nectar of* the Rhipe naa named "Leibfraaenmiloh," or milk of the Virgin; the tawny pressings of the Anda- lqrian oln8t*rg became known in lore as '^nnota Trinidad," or Holy Trinity.
In France two superior vintage* wow born under the parentage of the Chnrob and ►yen at the present day bear testimony in their names of White pnd Red Hermitage to their origin.
From that wonderful race, the Saracens, the Mediaeval Cbnroh learned the art of distilling and taught it to all Eorope.

In the emerald vales of Ireland theypro- daced the "potheenin the green glens of Scotland the "nsqnebaogh," in the sunny vineyards of France the "eau de vie in the sterile planes of Russia the "vodka," in the froj®n North of 8weden and Norway the "Kombrantivin." Nor was this enough. The ChnVian workers ransaoked th* far East for it* daintiest perfames, the West foi it* sweetes* fl 'vors.

Th*y extracted the aroma from the peach and pear, the inee' se from the lemon and j orange, the bloom of *he almond and the | savor (i the cherry They robbed the oinna^ men tree of its bark and the untme? of it* kernel. Then with t^e*e they made de'ivht- f.,1 rqnor*, yririch have g'orified our table*
. for gei eratioi s and shall endure unto the ' end of all time.

I The modest monks of La Trappe prodno^d . their masterp ece in "Trappistine." The poor Carthusian friars flashed upon the world ' glorious green and gold Chartreuse ; and the princely order of St. Benedict in the grand old abbey of Fecamp invented Benedictine, the finest drink that ever moistened mortal lips.

, Bat why continue ? Does it strengthen the argament to add that a creole monk in Loaisiana discovered "Parfait Amonr" ; that a German pastor first dis«oi*ed gold in a dainty fluid and ohns'ened it ' Eaa-de-Y*« d« Dantzi that a French friar tanght ns howto immortalize the orange ip "Onraro*," bow a provincial priest liquified the cherry in "Mara«chi io ; or how the Spanish eeoles;a«tio, from the sngar-oane gave ns "Santa-Croz" or ram of the Holy Cross 1 •

It is needles*. Bat it is w«ll that in our j^y fal libations we so should look haok pn ♦be year* and centuries with grat »ud affection to those humble hot noble pillars of the Cbnroh whose labor* have done so mnoh to lighten bright" and beantify the lives of all to-dav."
After Dr. Bedloe bad oonolndefl Mr- O'Day mildly remtrked that, rioly fbe wonder* of the (Charoh were pot half known or appreciated ' by its devotees,

div.head: TURKEY AND EGYPT
div.p: The rumour that Anglo-Egyptian troops have occupied Akabah is untrne, as only an in significant frontier dispute has ocoarred with the Turkish troops. The incident is now in the hands of the diplomatists at Constantinople.

In regard to reports issued there alleging the occupation by the Egyptian Government of territory Dear Akabah, it should be mentioned that it is not a question of ooonpation by E/ypt, bat of the ooonpation by the Tarka of a point named Tabah, on the 8inai Peninsula, about eight miles west of Akabah, and unquestionably Egyptian territory. The Porte, on being interrogated regarding the matter, stated that it was unacquainted with the feet, bat promised to withdraw its troops. rrhe performance of this promise is now being awaited. The Turks allege that Egypt is distributing a force of geodarmerie along the frontier. This, however, if true, does not ooneern Turkey, einoe it is a question of movements on Egyptian territory.
CORPORATION OF EGYPT.

Mr. Beckett has just returned from a months inspection of the railway and properties of the Corporation of Western Egypt Limited. As regards the railway the ronte offered prao- tically no diffioalties of oonstraotion although in places the grades will be as mnch as 1 in 40.
Fifty kilometres of the formation have been completed and the rails have already been laid to kilometre 12.

Progress most for the present be slower than it otherwise would until the arrival of the new locomotives and tracks which are soon to be shipped from England. Meantime the work is being carried on by a small looo- motive and trucks have been hired looally.

div.head: THE MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
div.p: MR ALDERSON'S DISCLAIMER

It has been erroneously assumed that the letter signed with the initials "A. G,"whieh was den on peed hy the Vioe-President of the Alexandria Municipality in our oolamns yesterday, was written by Mr. Geo. B. Alderson, who only resigned his position ss Municipal Councillor a few months ago. This theory as to the authorship of the letter was baaed on the fact that the initials of the writer of the letter were a reversal of the initials ot Mr. Alder- son's Christian and Surname. We are very pleased therefore to publish the following disclaimer from Mr. Alderson :—
To THE BDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Sir,

1 should be obliged if yon would insert the following statement in the Egyptian Gazette. I have nevsr nor do I ever intend to rend any communication to the Pres* for insertion without signing my name in fall. Truly Yonrs GEO. B. ALDERSON.
Ahxandrin, February 7.

div.head: HELOUAN RAILWAY

div.p: Med'nel el Fayoum, Tuesday.

Mr. Maohell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, accompanied by Lady Valda Maohell, yesterday visited L'-ke Mmris and to-ri»y left for Aboxs, they will retarn by way of Fidmin, Bilim and Senhoar.
This morning the Adviser inspected the Fayoum mounted police. To-morrow ha intends to visit Kelemshok.
Criminal Temlmo/ts.

The inhabitants of the Fayonm hope that the Adviser's visit will have some appreciable effect in lessening the number of crimes which threaten the well-being of the fellaheen and farmers in the Fayonmv Although the progress of thisprovinceisconrinnousandeveradvanoing, yet crimes are on the up-grade and the statistics for 1905 show that 195 crimes of a dangerous kind were perpetrated daring the past twelve month. This condition of public safety is by no means satisfactory. Many of the oases are due to professional criminals who form hands for purposes of brigandage under a leader. They are so organised as to be able to attack a whole esbet or a village, as happened lately at Dissia and Isbet Z zon, where the brigands tied the hands of the inhabitants and took everything they could carry off. The brigands laugh at the Molahis of ghafirs who have done nothing yet to arrest the miscreant*. The Government pay* too mnch money to the*e Molahis. who have done no good on behalf of rhe public seccrity, and it is expected that the Min'stry of the Interior wi'l abolish this system.
Bank of EQypt.
Comme- datura Lnsaato, Governor of the Bank of Egypt arrived here yesterday. He wa* received by Mr. Arbib, agent of the Fayonm branch.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Don Carlos, Dnke of Madrid, the donor of a tiepin to Chakonr Pacha, as weannoonoed yesterday, was born at Laibach in 1848 and olaiirs to be the legitimate King of Snain by the title of Charles VII. His father, Don Jaan was the brother of Don Carlos (Charles VI), known as the Count de Montemolin. in snpport of wVose claims the Carlist risings of 1848, 1855, aDd 1860 wereorganished. Charles VI, died without children, in 1861, and his rights devolved apon his brother, Don Jaan, who had married the Archduchess Maria Teresa of Austria, Princess of Modena. Their son, the present Don Carlos, who is with os now in Egypt, was educated ohiefly in Austria aud in 1867 be married Margaret de Bonrbon, Princess of Parma, danghter of the late Dnke Ferdinand Charles III. and Mademoiselle de Franoe, Daohess of Palma, sister of Henry V. of Franoe.

As the undisputed senior male heir of the Houfe of Bonrbon, Don Carlos would have a distinct right to the throne of Franoe in the event of a monarchical restoration, bat though frequently invited by the royalists of that country to pot forward his olaim, he has always abstained from doing so. His first w;fe Prinoe*s of Boarbon Parma died in 1893. leaving him five rhildren, the Infanta Blanca, D m Jaime, Prince of the Astoria, the Infanta Elvira, the infanta Beatrix, and the Infanta Alix. In 1894 he married Marie Berthe, Princess de Rohan, wh) has oome to Egypt with him,
Mostapha Pacha Fchmy, President of the Conncil of Ministers, intends to prolong his stay at Mena House Hotel, the weather at the present time being most delightful there.
His Excellenoy called on Lord Cromer yesterday.
Lord Cromer had an interview with M. de la Bonlinifere yesterday.
We are glad to hear that the Hon. Evelyn Baring is now quite oenvalescent.
Sir Vincent Corbett returns to Cairo on Friday.
Sir Vincent Caillard, the Hon. Bernard Francis Rollo and the Hon. Sidney Peel arrived at Cairo yesterday evening from Port Said.
Sir George and Lady Cooper have left Horsley Park for a few weeks in Egypt. Thay have chartered a special steamer on the Nile, and will, with some friends, go up to Assouan.
They left Cairo this morning by the steamer Colombia, specially chartered from the Anglo- Amerioan Nile Steamer and Hotel Company.

Sir George has spent considerably oVere quarter of a million à acquiring and improving the Hartley Park estate, the former home of the Heatheotes. He purchased it in 1901, and at once set about rebuilding the mansion, and 1 he decorations and furnishings are no* magnificent

Sir George until a few years ago was a solicitor in Elgin. He had married in 1887 the nieoe of Mr. Smith, of phioago, a man of very greit wealth, and when Mr. Smith died he iaberited an immense fortune. Abandoning the law for London,he porchtsed Captain Heywood Lonsdale's beautiful house in Groevenor-sqnare, and has entertained there a great deal daring the last two years. He also rents the magnificent deer forest G'eufeshie from Sir George Maophernon Grant.The baronetcy was a reward for gifts to charity.

Four incidents appear to show that the Russian revolutionaries are only biding the r time. Three accidental explosions ot bombs causing numerous deaths, oocurred atSos»o- wice, Odessa and at Bielostook. A Russian, of the name of Kowalewsky, was arrested yesterday evening at Ghent. His house contained 200 rifles, 50 revolvers and 20,000 cartridges.
The trial of 73 men of the Potemkin mutiny has begun at Sevastopol.
The Semenovsky regiment, notorious for its manner of suppressing the Mosoow troubles, has started to restore order on the Tran-Sibe- rian Railway.

It is understood that General Grodekoff w'll replace General Linievitch. The latter reports that General Rennenkanqf entered Chita unopposed on the 5th February. 200 Revolutionaries have been arrested. (Rent*)

A certain reaction among Unionists in favour of Mr, Balfour is apparent. It is now announced that no tariff reformer will oppose Mr. Balfour in the city, where an independent Liberal, Mr. Mason, has intimated his intention of standing.

Disturbances in connection with the in* ventorying of ohnrohes have ocoored at Alengon, Cherbourg and Saint Clande. In the latter Revolutionaries broke into the Cathedral, burned a confessional and threw a statue of the Madonna into the river. {Reuto^j

M. Loubet, in receiving the London Connty Councillors, proposed the toast of King Edward's health in the mo9t cordial terms, referring to His Majesty's efforts to cement the Anglo-French friendship both before and since his accession.
A portion of the Edinburgh Corporation wi'l visit Paris in April. The Municipality of Lyons has accepted an invitation to visit Manchester. (RmUtr)

M. Loubet, on receiving the members of the London County Council, stated that daring the term of his presidency he had laboured with all his strength for the purpose of establishing Anglo-French concord.
Mr. Cornwall replied that the English will be delighted if the visit of the members of the London County Council will contribute to a durable peace between the two nations.
M. Loubet toasted King Edward VII. (H.j

Reports continue ti arrive at the State Department from American agents in China regarding the rapid increase of anti-American teeling There are indications that all foreigners, except Japanese, will soon be equally affected. (Reuter.)
The imports during January amount to £53,500,000 and the exports to £30,750,000, showing each an increase of £5,750,000

The Emperor will go to Copenhagen OD board his yacht. He will only land for the funeral and will leave in the evening, that* avoiding forcing a meeting with the Duke of Cumberland in the family circle, the prospeat of which was causing considerable embarrassment. ( Reuter)

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON
div.p: The South has nothing to fear in the way of a large increase of the Egyptian cotton crop, according to Mr. Cope Whitehonse, the well known engineer and scholar who is spending the winter in Washington looking after the international features of his Lake Moeris irrigation project. Mr. Whitehonse is thoroughly familiar with conditions in Egypt, and he does not hesitate to say that the widely-heralded ABBOT an dam, instead of having the effeot of doubling the Egyptian cotton crop, as its projectors predicted, has really had no effeot save an unfavourable one. This year*8 crop, he say*, will probably be a trifle smaller than that of the year before tbs dam was commenced.

"In 1894," said Mr. Whitehonse to-day, "American cotton growers were told that there was an immense area cf adandoned land, admirably adapted to cotton cultivation, lying between the cultivated section of the Delta and the Mediterranean. In 1887, the late John Cardwell of Houston, then Consul General at Cairo, made an elaborate report on the oondi tion and prospeots of the country as a whole. He described the attempts made to show that Egypt could sapply itself and probably do a considerable export trade by exploiting an extended field oharged with petroleum, at a point on the Red Sea which has borne the name 'Petroleum desert' since the Greeks coined this now familiar eqnivalent for rock oil. He WAS skeptical of any possible competition with the United States, however, and it snbs2qdeatly became apparent that the large sums expended on the borings in the field were merely part of a financial scheme to benefit the speculative holders of Egyptian seonrities in London and Paris.

"In treating of cotton," Mr. Whitehonse continued, "Mr. Cardwell said that little o' that staple was produced prior to the time when the trade of ports in the ootton-growing States was oat off by the blockade daring the civil war. Egyptians then began to bend their energies to supply, so far as lay in their power, some of the resultant deficit. One dollar a pound was a great incentive, and the cultivation of cotton in the Nile valley beoame general. In 1886 87 the total cultivated area of Egypt was estimated by him at 4,498 520 acres, with 824 114 acres of cotton in lower Egypt and less th\n 50,000 acres to the south of Cairo. Only 21 4 per cent of the population was engaged in cetton culture. The cotton orop was tlieu a so t of by-prodact of the general agricultural operations, being grown for export after abundant provision had been made for a food supply of rioe, Indian com, barley, beaus, wheat to the value of £13,000,000, etc. Sugar cane laud in upper Egypt was worth £50 au aore.

"The Egyptian ootton was used in the United States in the manufacture of cotton velvets or plashes principally. It could Dever compete with Amerion sea island ootton at 30 or 35 cents for fine thread*, nor with the average quality of Southern growth, on account of the price The quality was also obviously limited to the ne:ghbourhood of a million Hores,so long as there was no Government inter ferecce with the food supply. Bat when the British took possession of the ministry of public works and of finance in 1883-4 ths cotton crop became the end and aim of all their administrative energies. They forced the farmers to abandon rice so that the water might be used for cotton, and by praotioaliy abolishing the importation of fresh seed and the substitution of a native seed known as mit afifi, the quantity was increased and the quality lowered to a point at which it could be used in the English milb». At a later period a reduction was made in the area allotted to sugar cane. Egyptian sugar, in beaatiful yellow crystals, was sent to Franoe to be used with beet sugars, being conveyed in French steamers, while the cotton went in British vessels to English and Scotch mills."

It was in 1887 that Mr. Cardwel^l took cognizance of Mr. Whitehonse's work, in his report he said that "the onrions historical and scientific researches of a citizen of the United States had unfolded a huge plan of irrigation, known to the anoients and the present Egyptian government, after at first turning a deaf ear to his propositions, seems at this time disposed to proof by this philosophy." But he added a warning that benefits would not be realized "nnless foreign power again re established decay .''Under the head "A Grand Scheme" he then described Mr. Whitehonse's Lake Moeris project. In the early pa^t of 1882, Mr. Whithoose visited Egypt and went into the desert, where he found a valley corresponding in shape, depth and position to that which he had found depicted on a map copied nearly 500 years before from a more ancient map drawn more than 100 years before that time. It was by the use of this valley, with a canal about eight miles in length leading off from the flooded area of the Nile about 70 miles upstream from Cairo, that it was expected to double the available supply of water -during the period known as low Nile. Athongh the great African river looms long and huge on the map, for more than three months every year it ceases to dis- ohargeany wateriato the Mediterranean. Hence, before there could be any increase in ootton cultivation it was necessary to store flood water, and the amonnt proposed to be stored by Mr. Whitehonse was 3 000,000,000 cubic yard . Tlrs ciuld have bseu obareed from the Ra'yan valley, with a depth of 220 feet and a snrface area cf 250 square miles, by allowing the Nile to raise the level of the proposed lake to that of the inondation in the adjacent valley, and then closing the alnice gates, to be opened in March. As the Nile ri*:e3 abont 20 feet, it was, and is, Mr. White- house's opinion that this difference wonld have been more than euffioent.

"I take m .ch interest in this question," wrote Mr. Cardwell in his report. "I desire to see the scholarly efforts and the persistent researches of one of my countrymen suooeed; to see American mind do rood as a counterbalance to harm done by European armies."

Bat years have elapsed and the swamps and sind-strewn regions of the Delta remain as they were when tha Texas man wa9 oonsul general at Cairo, and f)r 1700 years before that, although the soorpion infested and hyena haunted depths of tin "region of Gehenna" have been traversed, measured and explored by a score of experts employed by the Egyptian Government, or representing scientific societies of Europe and the United States.

"While the successful oarrying oat cf the project would obviously have a wonderfully stimulating effeot on ootton growing in Egypt," said Mr. Whitehonse in discussing this phase of the case," the ootton growers of the Sonth need not fear that a single acre will be added to Egypt's ootton area through my efforts for at least five years. In 1891 and again in 1894, it seemed certain that tin werk would be undertaken at once. In 1898 a contract was made for a reservoir dam at the first oataract; and even so well-informed a representative of the United State* as Hon F. C. Pen field, appoint ed by President Cleveland ventured the prediction that 1,600,030 aens would be added before 1908, wi*h an incase in the agricultural output of at least 20 per cent.

"But these expectations have proved to be baseless. The dam itself is a wall a mile and a quarter in length. The English engineers who designed it as a private specnlation for an English company declared that it woold offer no obstruction to the high Nile, but that the flood would pass as freely through the sluiceways as a river through the piers of a bridge. Oa August 8, last, when the reservoir should have been empty, the Nile had headed np over 30 feet, and wa9 tearing through 140 passages, abont 40 to 60 feet io length, and 7 to *1 in widih, at a rate of more than 50 miles an hour. Deep orevices had developed on the down side, and it was necessary to oons'ruot buttresses in great haste. It will take at least two yean to complete these and o^her repairs.

"The cot'oa crop has been increased by the transfer of sugar cane land to cotton oultiva tiou," con tin nod Mr. Whitahons**, "hnfc tho official reports show that the orops before 1898 when the contract for the dam was signed have actually exceeded those raised since its completion. There livs been a loud outcry to the effect; that a group of English speculators, of whom Sir Ernest Cassel was the principal, quietly aeqaired over million acres, at prioes ranging from the Government registrati6n fee of 10 cents per acre, up to $10 a id $20, and then agreed to build the dam ia order to raise prioes and enable them to onload the land on the French and English pub'ic daring the foar years the construction work wv3 in progress. Even Lord Cromer appears to hwa become alarmed at the impanding crash. The price of the lands was forced up to nearly $ '00 an aore. And when the speculators hare unloaded,the ground could not be remunerative t > the cultivator at any sach price. It ii freely alleged that the famous understaudiug between England and France was negotiated by King Edward at the request of Sir E neit Cassel to prevent an investigation of the nse of British influence aM the misappropriation of over $20,000,000 of tin revenues, which had bee lent to th3 English group to oarry on their speculative enterprises. The Duke of Con nanght was utilized to lay the oorn8r stone in 1833, and to inaugurate the dam on its completion in Ojtober. 1902. The change of Cabinet in England will lead to an investiga tion which will result in the restoration of many millions to the Egyptian treasury

"But to return to the ootton question," said Mr. Whitehonse in conclusion, "the Amerioan growers have nothing to fear. The Egyptian crop of this year is estimated to be no larger than that of 1897-8, or aboat 1,200,000 bales."

A resolution calling on the State department fir all papers relating to Mr. Whitehonse's operations in Egypt has been introduced by Senator Lodge and a lop tel, and the data is now io coarse of preparation at the department ( New Orleans Daily States.)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: Sir,—Apropos of the recent very interesting article in the "Gazette" on Egypt's egg industry, I may mention that I happen to know a big wholesale egg merchant in London with whom I have frequently conversed on this subject. His remarks may be thus summarised :—

"Egyptian eggs are inferior to all others. We only buy them when we can get no others. They are, as you know, exceedingly small and nothing is done to improve their size. Imports from other eastern countries have increased out of all proportion to those from Egypt because the natives have learned how to improve the size of the eggs. Egypt makes no progress in this respect. Worst of all, the "Mammies" are so carelessly packed that cases frequently come to us with three-fourths of them smashed "
From the foregoing remarks you will readily understand how it happens—to quote from your article—that "Eggs arrive in England at a time when the home production is exceedingly small."

There is here, however, a slight understatement of the actual facts. Egyptian eggs arrive in England at a time when both home production and importation from foreign countries are exceedingly small, because it is only at that period of the year that "Mammies" can find an English market. At all other times they are quite unsaleable. Surely, if my informant's strictures are warranted, something might be done to remedy the state of things vouched by him. Could not the Khedivial Agricultural Society take the matter up with advantage 1— Truly yours, OVUM.

div.head: THE BLUE NILE
div.p: Dr. Hayes, medical officer at the Suez Quarantine Office, has written a very interesting account ofbri travels through the Sudan to Lake Tsana in Western Abyssinia and back to Egypt ly the Valley of the Atbarc. The author while acting as medical inspector of the native ,,natter of Alexandria duriug 1902, the last cholera year, was chosen as the medical member of the expedition which was sent at the end of that year by the Egyptian Government to Lake Tsana. The other Englishmen of the expedition were Mr. Dupuis and Mr. Crawley. The main objeot of the expedition was of a very interesting nature. Aa the exploration of the Sudan proceeds, it becomes increasingly clear that it will itself use op all the extra water that the engineer iaTe likely to find for a long time to come. The cutting of the tndd on the White Nile has not resulted so far in any increase of the volome of the lower river, but in the reclamation of a good deal of land above Khartoum ; and the fi at effect of engineering works on the Bine Nile and Atbara and the tributaries of both will be the fertilization of the vast tracts of black "cotton-soil" which stretch from Berber to Kassala, Gedaref, and Gallabat These works are still in the future ; but preparations foi them ceaselessly occupy the minds of the So dan administrators,prompted and encouraged by Lord Cromer, whose paramount preoccupation it has been from first to lest to multiply the waters cf the Nile Basin. About three years ago a notable step was taken. After negotiations vith the Abyssinian Emperor, the expedition fod by two engineers and accompanied by Dr. Hayes despatched to Lake Tsar a, which receives and discharges the waters of the Abai River, known to os in its lower oourse as the Blue Nile. div.head: TRAVEL IN PALESTINE
div.p: Now that the season for travelling in Syria and Palestine has commenced and everything points to the popularity of that country being as great as ever we have the pleasure to give our visitors the following information which in >y prove of interest.
It may be said that there are two methods by which one may travel in Palestine, (1) by rail, carriage, and hotel, (2) by horseback, and camp.

By tho first means a considerable portion of the most interesting part of the country may be seen with no more fatigue than travelling in any other oonntry, thug, one may reach Jerusalem in 30 hours from Cairo, going by rail to Port Said, leaving there in the evening by steamer, arriving Jaffa early next morning,and Jaffa to Jerusalem by rail iu 4 hours.

In Jerusalem very fair hotel accommodation is available. Most of the excursions to points ot interest around the city may be visited by carriage, including Hebron, the Pools of Solomon, Jericho, Bethlehem, the JordaD, and the Dead Sea. For this trip from Jaffa back to Jaffa, covering eight days, and including all the above excursions, services of a dragomau, hotel accommodation, aqd other ncoessary expenses for sightseeiBg etc, Thos. Cook and Son charge from £11.5.0 upwards, aooordingto the number of passengers.

From Haifa, where steamers frrquently touch, au excursion is ear ily made to Nsaireth, Tiberias, and the lake of Galilee, and baok. There are very fair hotels at Haifa, Nazsreth and Tiberias, and carriage road throughout. For this trip, covsring 7 days from Haifa hack to Haifa, including carriage for the entire rosnd, services of a dragoman, hotel accommodation, sight seeing expenses eto the charge is from £9 upwards, according to the number of passengers.

From Bayrout the railway runs to Damascus and Baalbeo, and in all three places there is very fair hotel aooommodatiou. For this trip ocoupying 7 days from Beyront back to Beyrout, the charge is from £ 10 upwards, according to number of passengers.

Those wishing to visit other parts of the oouDtry where carriage roads or railways have not yet been constructed, and in which no suitable hotel accomodation is to be foand, must make use of the second means of travel, namely horseback, and camp, and it may safely be said that given favourable weather, no more delightfal mode of travelling can be im»gin?d. The horses are good and quiet, and the day's journey is never so long aa to be fatigaing to anyone in fairly good health, and need not be feared even by those e ntirely unaooustomed to riding. The oamp accommodation is RB com fortable as any good hotel, the slrepiug tents ig furnished with camp bedsteads, mat tresses, blankets, sheets eto, the floors are carpeted, and in fact every convenienrg is provided. The meals are excellent and well served, and travellers need have no hesitation in undertaking the journey by this mode of travel to any part of the country, hower remote, including the Sinaitio Desert, the country east of th9 Jordan, the Hanran, the Lebanon, or even farther afield to the Euphrates Valley and Bagdad. Thos. Cook & Son undertake, for a fixed charge per day, to relieve the traveller of all responsibility, to provide camp eqaip meat, dragoman, oook, servants, horses, baggage mules, and every requisite. The rate is as low as £ 1:5:0 per day iu the oase of a party of ten visiting tbrnearer portion of the country, and rises slightly for smaller numb3rs of passergers, or those de firing to visit the more remote districts.

They have their own offices, with their own salaried representatives, in Jaffi, Jerusalem, Haifa, and Beyroat, and the firm is di.eotly responsible to their travellers for all the arrangements, in other words, travellers under their oare are dealing always with the salaried rep rasentative3 of Messrs Tho*. Cook and Son, and never with irresponsible dragomans or aub-ooutractors. They own by far the largest and best oamp equipment in the country, and have in their employ the most experienced and reliable dragomans and oamp servants of all kinds, as well as the best boatmen at the various ports.
Having an experience of travel in Palestine for»hepa8t35 years, their arrangements are

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: TheE0^Ptta.H(Ba3CttC has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes bv which they may travel homewards. lireRt care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe. This depends partly upon the month in whjch you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many oth$r places in Europe They are as follows :— The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton,London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows :— Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days Alexandria to Messina ... 3 „ Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles 5 „ Alexandria toVenice and Trieste... 4 „ Alexandria to Naples 3 „ Port Said to Genoa 5 „ Port Said to Naples 4 „ Alexandria to Constantinople ... 4 , Alexandria to Pirteus 2 „ ( Port Said to Gibraltar 7 „ The steamers, of the P. & 0. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt. As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4j hours. The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni; Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg. The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste*Vienna express from Alexandria. As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but corafortab'e ships liave enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats,'* having been specially built to caijy the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England yo will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said

div.head: SICILY
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rnbattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the mo>t charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is »he station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.c. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.c. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an anoient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Grivannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday j during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days. NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from j Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steam-; ere, which leave daily. One cannot approach j Naples or leave it without wishing to explore ; some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its hny—Castellamare and Sorrento. The | small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you J can drive tool will take you on to Capri. From Naples to ROME is a train journey of | but five hours. All who can will devote at t least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here. Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City oj Flowers and its surrounding country. hi Florence itself the chnrcheg and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excur- sions should not be omitted. The Caseine is j the most attractive and fashionable promenade ! in Florence, whilst the Viale dei ColH, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 33 years ; ago, goes winding up through the hills a ! distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that te Vallom- ■ brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero' thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible he made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It \a a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba). —The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one%of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously oool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer. The patriarchal home of Italy's most an- eient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delignt to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs. From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail. MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAG- GIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hoor you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY CONT.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, men slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace^ of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by tram by way of Monza : Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbiat and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza ou Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and- three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs." LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprinoand M. Generose. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minntes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild olimate, and vs an excellent winter resort. The church Madonnb-del Sasso, situated above the town,is worth a visit, iCsTt^contains interest- Entombmenv by Ciseri, and The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion. LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Like 0/Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigit Pilatue, Bur gen- stock and Sonnsnberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a souroe of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titles, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand ; extending from Monte Bosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn. THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resortand the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous .waterfalls, Giessbach, Trurnmelbach and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed. CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,300 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE AND IONIAN ISLES
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be presen' at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara forlrhich a special train is run from Athens. Itf is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the PCI »ery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
